metadata.notes: Batch 1 audit: Aamina Ahmad through Arthur Bradford

writers.name: Aamina Ahmad
writers.bio: Pakistani-American novelist and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut novel The Return of Faraz Ali won the L.A. Times Art Seidenbaum Award and was named a Best Book of the Year by The New York Times and NPR.
awards: Writers' Guild of Great Britain First Book Prize

photo.notes: Photo available on official author website and Penguin Random House publisher page

writers.name: Adam Bradley
writers.bio: Literary scholar and Lewis & Clark College alum who pioneered the academic study of hip-hop lyrics as poetry. Professor at UCLA and founding director of the Laboratory for Race & Popular Culture.
notableWorks: Book of Rhymes: The Poetics of Hip Hop

photo.notes: Photo on UCLA faculty page; additional photos by Stephanie Yantz in UCLA College Magazine profile

writers.name: Ada Lim√≥n
writers.bio: The 24th U.S. Poet Laureate and the first Latina to hold the position. Her collection The Carrying won the National Book Critics Circle Award, and she was appointed to a historic two-year second term as laureate.

photo.notes: Multiple photos on Wikimedia Commons; also Library of Congress photos by Shawn Miller

writers.name: Alan Shapiro
writers.bio: American poet and former William R. Kenan Jr. Distinguished Professor at UNC Chapel Hill. His collection Night of the Republic was a finalist for both the National Book Award and the Griffin Poetry Prize.

photo.attribution: UNC Dept. of English / Steve Exum
photo.notes: Photos on UNC English department pages; photo by Steve Exum in Wilson Library; Griffin Poetry Prize page also has photo

writers.name: Alexia Arthurs
writers.bio: Jamaican-American fiction writer and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut story collection How to Love a Jamaican won the Paris Review's Plimpton Prize and explores the Jamaican immigrant experience.

photo.notes: Author photo by Rose Marie Cromwell on official website and publisher pages

writers.name: Alexis M. Smith
writers.bio: Pacific Northwest novelist whose debut Glaciers was an Oregon Book Award finalist. Her second novel Marrow Island won the Pacific Northwest Booksellers Association Award and a Lambda Literary Award.

photo.notes: Photo by Annie Beedy on Tin House author page

writers.name: Alix Ohlin
writers.bio: Canadian novelist and short story writer. Her novel Dual Citizens was shortlisted for the Scotiabank Giller Prize, and her collection We Want What We Want won the Lambda Literary Award for Bisexual Literature.
awards: Rogers Writers' Trust Fiction Prize shortlist

photo.notes: Photos by Emily Cooper and Stephanie Noritz; available on official website, UBC Creative Writing faculty page, and Penguin Random House

writers.name: Ama Codjoe
writers.bio: American poet and dancer. Her collection Bluest Nude won the 2023 Lenore Marshall Poetry Prize and a Whiting Award. She was appointed the second Poet-in-Residence at the Guggenheim Museum.

photo.attribution: David Heald / Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation
photo.notes: Photo by David Heald for Guggenheim Museum; also photos on Poetry Foundation and official website

writers.name: Anis Mojgani
writers.bio: Spoken word poet and Oregon's 10th Poet Laureate (2020-2024). He won back-to-back National Poetry Slam titles in 2005-2006, and his book The Feather Room was a National Book Award nominee.
awards: Academy of American Poets Laureate Fellowship

photo.notes: Press photos available for download on official website (The Piano Farm); Oregon Cultural Trust also has photos from laureate tenure

writers.name: Anna Keesey
writers.bio: Oregon-based novelist and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut Little Century, set in 1900 Central Oregon, was praised by The Washington Post as a work about 'who will inherit the earth.'
awards: National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship

photo.notes: Photo on Linfield University faculty page; also available on Macmillan author page and MacDowell artist page

writers.name: Arthur Bradford
writers.bio: American writer and filmmaker whose debut story collection Dogwalker was praised by David Sedaris as the work of 'the most outlandish and energetic writer I can think of.' His stories have appeared in McSweeney's and Esquire.

photo.notes: Photo on MacDowell artist page; also IMDB page and DC/DOX festival page
